case_name: Moti Singh and Jagdamba Prasad v. State

facts.text: Criminal Appeals Nos. 146 and 147 of 1962 filed by Moti Singh and Jagdamba Prasad.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPFLLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeals Nos. 146 and 147 of 1962. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 2, 1962, of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Appeals Nos. 157 and 158 of 1961 and Criminal Revision No. 384 of 1961.

facts.text: Appeals by special leave from judgment and order dated February 2, 1962 of Allahabad High Court in Criminal Appeals Nos. 157 and 158 of 1961 and Criminal Revision No. 384 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 2, 1962, of the Allahabad High Court in Criminal Appeals Nos. 157 and 158 of 1961 and Criminal Revision No. 384 of 1961. S. R. Chari, Ravinder Narain, J. B. Daduchanji and 0. Mathur, for the appellants.

facts.text: Moti Singh and Jagdamba Prasad along with five others convicted by Sessions Judge of Unnao under sections 148, 302/149, 307/149 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: Moti Singh and jagdamba Prasad, appellants, together with five other persons, were companyvicted by the Sessions judge of Unnao of offences under s. 148, 302 read with 149 and 307 read with 149 I. P. C.

facts.text: Each convicted person sentenced to life imprisonment under section 302 read with section 149 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: Each of them was sentenced to life imprisonment under s. 302 read with s. 149 1. P. C. On appeal, the High Court acquitted the other five persons of the various offences.

facts.text: High Court acquitted the other five persons of various offences.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal, the High Court acquitted the other five persons of the various offences. The companyviction of the appellants under s. 148 1. P. C., was also set aside, but their companyviction for the offences under ss. 302 and 307 read with s. 149 were altered to companyviction for offences under ss. 302 and 307 read with s. 34 1. P. C.

facts.text: High Court set aside conviction of appellants under section 148 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The companyviction of the appellants under s. 148 1. P. C., was also set aside, but their companyviction for the offences under ss. 302 and 307 read with s. 149 were altered to companyviction for offences under ss. 302 and 307 read with s. 34 1. P. C.

facts.text: High Court altered conviction of appellants to sections 302/34 and 307/34 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: but their companyviction for the offences under ss. 302 and 307 read with s. 149 were altered to companyviction for offences under ss. 302 and 307 read with s. 34 1. P. C. On the application of Krishna Kumar, brother of one of the persons who had been murdered, the High Court enhanced the sentence of the appellants for the offence of murder to death.

facts.text: High Court enhanced sentence of appellants for murder to death on application of Krishna Kumar, brother of one murdered person.

anchor.surface_text: On the application of Krishna Kumar, brother of one of the persons who had been murdered, the High Court enhanced the sentence of the appellants for the offence of murder to death. Moti Singh and jagdamba Prasad have preferred these appeals respectively, after obtaining special leave from this Court.

facts.text: Incident occurred on February 9, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: The incident took place on February 9, 1960. Gaya Charans injuries were examined by Dr. Bhatnagar the same day.

facts.text: Several persons lost their lives in the incident.

anchor.surface_text: It is number necessary to detail the facts of the incident in which several persons lost their lives and for participation in which incident the appellants were companyvicted, as we are of- opinion that the companyviction cannot be maintained on the basis of the evidence on record as appreciated by the High Court.

facts.text: Eye witnesses deposed that accused party fired with guns and pistols from inside and outside the room on one side of the passage and from the seori cattle shed on the other side when victim party passed along the passage.

anchor.surface_text: All the eye witnesses of the incident deposed in practically identical terms about the progress of the incident in which it was alleged that the members of the accused party fired with guns and pistols both from inside and outside the room on one side of the passage and also from the seori  cattle shed  on the other side of the passage when the victim party passed along the passage.

facts.text: High Court doubted firing from cattle shed and acquitted Sheo Shankar, Jagjiwan and Shankar Dayal.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court felt doubtful about the firing of the shots from the cattle shed, and companysequently acquitted Sheo Shankar, jagjiwan and Shankar Dayal who were said to be mainly the persons who had fired from that place.

facts.text: High Court believed prosecution version of firing from the room and later from the platform.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court, however, believed the prosecution version of the firing from the room and later from the platform. It appears that the, High Court believed this version because the prosecution witnesses stated so and because the statements exhibits Kha 5, Kha 8 and Kha 75 mentioned about the shots being fired from those places.

facts.text: Gaya Charan made statement Ex. Kha 75, naming Jagdamba, Phunnar, Moti and one man as firing gunshots.

anchor.surface_text: The dying declaration Ex. Ka-75  Kha 75  of Gaya Charan appears to be a companylete account of the occurrence and the assailants as seen by him, for he stated Lallan, Chandu, Raj Narain, Sardar, Sri Prakash were going to the bazar. Shots were fired from front, jagdamba, Phunnar, Moti and one man whom I know by face fired gunshots on us.

facts.text: Lallan, Chandu, Raj Narain, Sardar, Sri Prakash were going to the bazar when shots fired.

anchor.surface_text: for he stated Lallan, Chandu, Raj Narain, Sardar, Sri Prakash were going to the bazar. Shots were fired from front, jagdamba, Phunnar, Moti and one man whom I know by face fired gunshots on us.

facts.text: Jagdamba Prasad remained absconding till arrest on September 30, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: It also took into companysideration the fact that he remained absconding till his arrest on September 30, 1960, the incident having taken place on February 9, 1960.

facts.text: Gaya Charan's injuries examined by Dr. Bhatnagar on February 9, 1960: two gun shot wounds of entry, dangerous to life.

anchor.surface_text: The incident took place on February 9, 1960. Gaya Charans injuries were examined by Dr. Bhatnagar the same day. He found two gun shot wounds of entry 1/4 x 1/4 up to the depth of abdomen and companysidered those injuries to be caused by gun shot and to be dangerous to life.

facts.text: Gaya Charan died on March 1, 1960 in Kanpur.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-Inspector Puttu Lal, P.W. 24, has deposed that it was known on March 1, 1960 that Gaya Charan had died in Kanpur and that when he reached the Bhairon Ghat he learnt that the dead body of Gaya Charan had been burnt a companyple of hours before.

facts.text: No evidence that Gaya Charan died due to injuries received in incident.

anchor.surface_text: There is numberevidence on record as to what caused Gaya Charans death. In this state of evidence the finding of the Sessions judge that Gaya Charan must have died on account of the injuries received in the incident cannot be held to be a good finding.

facts.text: Ram Shankar received gun shot wound dangerous to life but survived.

anchor.surface_text: In this companynection our attention was drawn to the fact that Ram Shankar who was also injured in that incident had received one gun shot wound -I x 1/4 up to the depth of his abdomen above the right end of upper border of Syihphysis Pubes, and that injury was also companysidered by the Doctor to be dangerous to life, but fortunately Ram Shankar did number succumb to the injury.

facts.text: Supreme Court holds dying declaration Ex. Kha 75 of Gaya Charan inadmissible because death not proved due to incident injuries.

anchor.surface_text: We find that there is numberevidence to support that finding and hold that Gaya Charan is number proved to have died due to the injuries received in the incident. The effect of this finding is that the alleged dying declaration of Gaya Charan,, Ex. Kha 75, cannot be admissible in evidence.

facts.text: Supreme Court acquits Moti Singh and Jagdamba Prasad.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly allow the appeals, set a de the order of the High Court and acquit Moti Singh and jagdamba Prasad of the offences they were companyvicted of.

facts.text: Judgment delivered on January 23, 1963 by RAGHUBAR DAYAL, J.

anchor.surface_text: 1963. January 23. The judgment of the Court was delivered by RAGHUBAR DAYAL, J.-Moti Singh and jagdamba Prasad, appellants, together with five other persons, were companyvicted by the Sessions judge of Unnao of offences under s. 148, 302 read with 149 and 307 read with 149 I. P. C.

facts.text: Deaths of Lallan and Matrumal in the incident.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore hold that Moti Singh and jagdamba Prasad have number been proved to have taken art in that incident on February 9, 1960, which part to the deaths of Lallan and Matrumal and the causing of hurt to several other persons.

issues.text: Whether prior statements of disbelieved witnesses (Exs. Kha 5 and Kha 8) recorded by a Magistrate can be used as independent substantive evidence in support of other prosecution evidence?

anchor.surface_text: Those statements could have been used only in either corroborating or contradicting the statements of these Witnesses in Court. If those witnesses were not to be believed, their previous statements could not be used as independent evidence in support of the other prosecution evidence.

issues.text: Whether Gaya Charan died on account of the gunshot injuries received in the incident of February 9, 1960?
Whether the statement Ex. Kha 75 of Gaya Charan is admissible as a dying declaration under clause (d) of s. 32 of the Evidence Act?

anchor.surface_text: Clause  d  of s. 32 of the evidence Act makes a statement of a person who has died relevant only when that statement is made by a person as to the cause of his death or as to any of the circumstances of the transaction which resulted in his death, in cases in which the cause of that persons death companyes into question. When Gaya Charan is number proved to have died as a result of the injuries received in the incident, his statement cannot be said to be the statement as to the cause of his death or as to any of the circumstances of the transaction which resulted in his death.

issues.text: Whether the remaining prosecution evidence is sufficient to establish beyond reasonable doubt that Moti Singh and Jagdamba Prasad were among the assailants?

anchor.surface_text: When this evidence is to be ignored as inadmissible, the remaining evidence on the record according to the view of the High Court, was insufficient to establish beyond reasonable doubt that these two persons were among the assailants. The appellants deserve the benefit of that doubt.

issues.text: Whether there were five or more assailants such as to attract offences under s. 148 and s. 149 IPC?

anchor.surface_text: The number of assailants mentioned in the dying declaration Ex. Kha. 75 is only four., It is doubtful if the assailants were more than four in number. No offence under section 148 was therefore companymitted and section 149 P.C. is number applicable.

issues.text: Whether the reference to 'Moti' in the dying declaration Ex. Kha 75 specifically identifies the appellant Moti Singh, given multiple persons named Moti in the village?

anchor.surface_text: With regard to the criticism for the accused about the indefiniteness of the description of Moti in the dying declaration of Gaya Charan when there were three persons by the name of Moti in the village, the High Court said We have numberdoubt that he is mentioned in the dying declaration. How they arrived at that companyclusion is number clear from the judgment.

Those statements could have been used only in either corroborating or contradicting the statements of these Witnesses in Court.

arguments.claim: The dying declaration Ex. Kha 75 is inadmissible in evidence.

anchor.surface_text: It follows that if this alleged dying declaration of Gaya Charan be inadmissible in evidence as urged for the appellants, the appeals have to be allowed and the conviction of the appellants set aside. The incident took place on February 9, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: It is not necessary to detail the facts of the incident in which several persons lost their lives and for participation in which incident the appellants were convicted, as we are of- opinion that the conviction cannot be maintained on the basis of the evidence on record as appreciated by the High Court.

holdings.text: Statements of disbelieved witnesses (Exs. Kha 5 and Kha 8) recorded by Magistrate cannot be used as independent substantive evidence.

anchor.surface_text: Those statements could have been used only in either corroborating or contradicting the statements of these Witnesses in Court. If those witnesses were not to be believed, their previous statements could not be used as independent evidence in support of the other prosecution evidence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Prior statements under Evidence Act can only corroborate or contradict court testimony, not serve as substantive evidence if witnesses disbelieved.

holdings.text: Gaya Charan is not proved to have died due to the injuries received in the incident.
holdings.reasoning_summary: No direct evidence on cause of death; dangerous nature of injuries insufficient as similar injury survivor (Ram Shankar) exists; Sessions Judge finding unsupported.

holdings.text: Dying declaration Ex. Kha 75 of Gaya Charan is inadmissible under clause (d) of s. 32 Evidence Act.
holdings.reasoning_summary: s.32(d) requires cause of death in question; since not proved death resulted from incident injuries, statement neither relates to cause nor circumstances thereof.

holdings.text: Remaining prosecution evidence insufficient to establish beyond reasonable doubt that appellants were among the assailants.

anchor.surface_text: When this evidence is to be ignored as inadmissible, the remaining evidence on the record according to the view of the High Court, was insufficient to establish beyond reasonable doubt that these two persons were among the assailants.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court itself viewed other evidence insufficient once key supports (prior statements, dying decl) excluded; appellants get benefit of doubt.

holdings.text: Conviction cannot be maintained on the basis of the evidence on record as appreciated by the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: It is not necessary to detail the facts of the incident in which several persons lost their lives and for participation in which incident the appellants were convicted, as we are of- opinion that the conviction cannot be maintained on the basis of the evidence on record as appreciated by the High Court.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Overall assessment leads to conclusion that prosecution fails to prove participation after excluding inadmissible evidence.

holdings.text: Moti Singh and Jagdamba Prasad have not been proved to have taken part in the incident on February 9, 1960.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore hold that Moti Singh and jagdamba Prasad have not been proved to have taken part in that incident on February 9, 1960, which led to the deaths of Lallan and Matrumal and the causing of hurt to several other persons.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Exclusion of dying declaration and improper evidence leaves case unproved beyond doubt.

holdings.text: Appeals allowed; High Court order set aside; appellants acquitted of all offences.

anchor.surface_text: We accordingly allow the appeals, set aside the order of the High Court and acquit Moti Singh and jagdamba Prasad of the offences they were convicted of.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative effect of evidentiary failings warrants acquittal.
